fact_list.fact_text: Driver's physical and mental condition can affect their driving.
Conditions that affect driving include vision, physical health, mental state, consumption of alcohol and drugs.
Eighty percent of the information perceived while driving comes through the driver's eyes.
Drivers should not fix their eyes on a particular object for longer than necessary while driving.
Drivers are advised to move their eyes about every two seconds while driving.
Drivers should take regular glances at the rear view mirrors every five to ten seconds.
Vehicle speed increase reduces the driver's field of vision.
Tiredness, giddiness, and being unwell can affect concentration on the road.
Drivers who feel unwell or tired are advised not to drive.
Anger, worry, and stress can reduce concentration and lead to rash or careless driving.
Consumption of alcohol and certain types of drugs affects judgment, concentration, and reaction time while driving.
Drivers on medication should check with their doctor if the prescribed medicine affects their driving ability.
Drivers should not drive if prescribed medication affects their driving ability.
It is unsafe to drive after consuming alcohol.
It is an offense for a person to drive or attempt to drive while under the influence of alcohol.
Drivers suspected of being under the influence of alcohol are required to undergo a breath analyzer test.
A person with a BAC exceeding 80mg per 100ml of blood is considered incapable of controlling a vehicle properly.
Adverse weather conditions affect a driverâ€™s ability to see and be seen.
Drivers are advised to reduce speed to maneuver safely in bad weather conditions.
Drivers should not out-drive the actual distance they can see clearly.
Drivers are advised to switch on headlights to see more clearly and to be more visible in bad weather conditions.
Drivers should turn on the demister to clear mist on the windscreen during bad weather.
If visibility is poor, drivers should stop safely with hazard lights turned on and proceed when conditions are favorable.
Drivers should use a faster front windscreen wiper speed when driving in heavy rain.
Stopping distance on a wet road increases to about twice the distance on a dry road due to less friction between tires and the wet road surface.
Hard braking on a wet road can cause vehicles to skid or spin.
Drivers should quickly release the brake pedal and apply intermittent braking if wheels lock accidentally on a wet road.
Driving at a slower speed on a wet road is advised to avoid dangerous situations.
